{
  "article_text": [
    "the tannaka  krein theorem by woronowicz  @xcite recovers a compact quantum group from its tensor category of finite - dimensional representations , together with the forgetful functor to the tensor category of hilbert spaces .",
    "we shall prove an analogue of this result for @xmath0-quantum groups , that is , quantum groups generated by manageable multiplicative unitaries .",
    "our result asserts that an isomorphism between the tensor categories of hilbert space representations that does not change the underlying hilbert spaces lifts to an isomorphism of the underlying hopf @xmath1-algebras .",
    "more generally , we shall explain how to extract multiplicative unitaries from representation categories and how to lift tensor functors between representation categories to morphisms of multiplicative unitaries .",
    "this article grew out of a suggestion by david bcher to clarify the construction of a semidirect product multiplicative unitary from a braided multiplicative unitary in @xcite .",
    "a braided multiplicative unitary is supposed to describe a braided @xmath0-quantum group , which should be a yetter ",
    "drinfeld algebra over some other @xmath0-quantum group , equipped with a comultiplication @xmath2 into its yetter  drinfeld twisted tensor square .",
    "the semidirect product is constructed in @xcite by writing down a unitary and checking that it is multiplicative .",
    "the data of a braided multiplicative unitary consists of four unitaries , subject to seven conditions .",
    "all four unitaries must appear in the explicit formula , and all seven conditions must be used in the proof that the semidirect product is multiplicative . thus the direct verification in  @xcite is rather complicated .",
    "here we offer a conceptual explanation for this construction .",
    "the main idea behind this is the theory of regular objects in tensor categories by pinzari and roberts  @xcite .",
    "we prefer to call them natural right absorbers because the adjective `` regular '' is already used for too many other purposes .",
    "a natural right absorber in  @xmath3 gives rise to a multiplicative unitary  @xmath4 and a tensor functor from  @xmath3 to the tensor category of hilbert space representations of  @xmath4 .",
    "representations of the semidirect product multiplicative unitary should be equivalent to representations of the braided multiplicative unitary .",
    "this idea already appears in a special case in  @xcite .",
    "here we extend this result to the general case . starting with a braided multiplicative unitary ,",
    "we define its representation category and describe a natural right absorber in it by combining two rather obvious pieces .",
    "the corresponding multiplicative unitary turns out to be the semidirect product .",
    "we also show that the functor from representations of the braided multiplicative unitary to representations of the semidirect product is an isomorphism of categories .",
    "the most difficult point here is to prove that any representation of the semidirect product comes from a representation of the braided multiplicative unitary .",
    "the semidirect product comes with a projection , which is another multiplicative unitary linked to it by pentagon - like equations .",
    "we interpret this projection through a projection on the representation category .",
    "more generally , we show that any tensor functor between representation categories that does not change the underlying hilbert spaces lifts to a morphism between the associated multiplicative unitaries as defined in @xcite .",
    "this also implies the weak tannaka  krein theorem for @xmath0-quantum groups mentioned above . and it gives yet another equivalent description of quantum groups with projection .",
    "we are going to recall the notion of a ( right ) regular object of a tensor category from  @xcite .",
    "we call such an object a natural right absorber , avoiding the overused adjective `` regular '' . going beyond  @xcite",
    ", we show that different natural right absorbers give isomorphic multiplicative unitaries with respect to the morphisms of @xmath0-quantum groups defined in @xcite .",
    "we also add a further equivalent description of such quantum group morphisms through functors between representation categories , and we show that isomorphic multiplicative unitaries generate isomorphic @xmath0-quantum groups as expected .",
    "let  @xmath5 denote the @xmath6-category of hilbert spaces .",
    "this is a symmetric monoidal category for the usual tensor product  @xmath7 of hilbert spaces , with the obvious associator @xmath8 , the obvious unit transformations @xmath9 , and the obvious symmetric braiding @xmath10    let  @xmath3 be a @xmath6-category with a faithful forgetful functor @xmath11 .",
    "faithfulness allows us to assume that @xmath12 for all objects @xmath13 ( we write  @xmath14 for objects of categories , @xmath15 for arrows ) .",
    "we say that @xmath16 _ comes from  @xmath3 _ if it belongs to the image of @xmath17 .",
    "we think of objects in  @xmath3 as hilbert spaces with some extra structure , such as a representation of a ( braided ) multiplicative unitary ; the morphisms are those bounded linear maps that preserve this extra structure .",
    "motivated by this interpretation , we assume the following throughout this article :    [ assum : identity_arrow_equal ] if @xmath18 and the identity map on this hilbert space comes from an arrow @xmath19 , then @xmath20 .",
    "we also want a functor @xmath21 with @xmath22 .",
    "thus  @xmath23 acts as the identity on arrows , and the arrows @xmath24 in  @xmath3 are exactly all bounded linear operators @xmath25 .",
    "we abbreviate @xmath26 for @xmath27 .",
    "we interpret  @xmath23 as the functor that equips a hilbert space  @xmath28 with the `` trivial '' extra structure to get an object in  @xmath3 .",
    "we assume that  @xmath3 is also a monoidal category , but not necessarily braided , such that both @xmath29 and  @xmath23 are strict monoidal functors .",
    "this means , first , that @xmath30 for all @xmath13 and @xmath31 for all @xmath32 . secondly , that the tensor unit in  @xmath3 is @xmath33 , which @xmath29 maps back to the tensor unit in  @xmath5 .",
    "thirdly , @xmath29 and  @xmath23 map associators and unit transformations in  @xmath3 to the obvious associators and unit transformations in  @xmath5 . finally , we require the following assumption , which is trivial to check in all cases we shall consider :    [ assum : arrow_cancellative ] let @xmath34 and let @xmath35 be such that @xmath36 comes from an arrow @xmath37 in  @xmath3 or @xmath38 comes from an arrow @xmath39 in  @xmath3 .",
    "then  @xmath40 itself comes from an arrow @xmath41 in  @xmath3 .    a _ hilbert space tensor category _",
    "is a monoidal @xmath6-category  @xmath3 with a faithful , strict monoidal functor @xmath11 and a strict monoidal functor @xmath21 satisfying @xmath22 and assumptions [ assum : identity_arrow_equal ] and  [ assum : arrow_cancellative ] .",
    "[ exa : corepcat ] let @xmath42 be a multiplicative unitary .",

    "quick computations show that this is again a representation , that  @xmath58 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}$ ] is associative , and that  @xmath59 is a tensor unit , with the usual associator and unit transformations from  @xmath5 .",
    "since an operator of the form @xmath60 for @xmath61 commutes with  @xmath62 , it is an intertwiner for @xmath63 if and only if  @xmath40 is one for  @xmath64 .",
    "hence assumption  [ assum : arrow_cancellative ] holds .",
    "assumption  [ assum : identity_arrow_equal ] holds because our objects are indeed hilbert spaces with extra structure .",
    "[ lem : sigma_over_trivial ] let @xmath13 , @xmath65 .",

    ", then we get arrows @xmath74 in @xmath17 with @xmath75 by taking @xmath76 , where @xmath77 , @xmath78 , and where we implicitly identify @xmath79 .",
    "for the converse , let @xmath80 be a net of finite - rank projections converging weakly to the identity operator on  @xmath28 .",
    "then we get endomorphisms @xmath81 , which still converge weakly to the identity operator .",
    "since @xmath82 is weakly closed , it suffices to lift @xmath83 to an arrow in  @xmath3 for all  @xmath84 and then take a limit . writing the finite - rank projection  @xmath85 as a sum of rank-1 projections , we further reduce to the lifting of an operator of the form @xmath86 for a unit vector @xmath70 .",

    "let  @xmath28 be a hilbert space .",
    "then any bounded linear operator @xmath88 comes from an arrow @xmath89 in  @xmath3 .",
    "conversely , let @xmath90 be an object of  @xmath3 with @xmath91 such that any bounded linear map @xmath92 comes from an arrow @xmath93 .",
    "hence the identity map @xmath94 comes from an arrow in  @xmath3 by lemma  [ lem : sigma_over_trivial ]",
    ". then @xmath95 by assumption  [ assum : identity_arrow_equal ] .",

    "the naturality of  @xmath105 says that arrows @xmath41 in  @xmath3 are intertwiners @xmath137 . to prove that we have a fully faithful functor",

    "so let @xmath138 be an intertwiner @xmath137 .",
    "then we get an arrow @xmath139 since  @xmath40 is an intertwiner , the forgetful functor maps this composite arrow to @xmath140 .",

    "thus any intertwiner comes from an arrow in  @xmath3 .",
    "this finishes the proof that the functor from  @xmath3 to the category of right representations of  @xmath130 is fully faithful . by construction ,",
    "our functor intertwines the forgetful functors to  @xmath5 .",
    "the condition [ en : natural_absorber2 ] says exactly that @xmath108 is the tensor product representation @xmath141 .",
    "since we assumed  @xmath29 to map the associator and unit transformations in  @xmath3 to the usual ones in  @xmath5 , the functor @xmath142 from  @xmath3 to the representation category of  @xmath130 is a strict tensor functor .",
    "we have not found a `` nice '' characterisation when the functor @xmath143 is essentially surjective , that is , when every representation of  @xmath130 comes from an object of  @xmath3 .",
    "[ exa : left_corep ] let @xmath42 be a multiplicative unitary .",

    "the natural intertwiner is @xmath154 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb w^ { } } )    \\to ( { \\mathcal{k}}\\otimes{\\mathcal{h } } , 1_{{\\mathcal{k}}}{\\mathbin{\\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline , x=.75ex , y=.75ex ] \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb w^{}}).\\ ] ]    next we want to prove that the multiplicative unitaries for two natural right absorbers of  @xmath3 are isomorphic in the category of multiplicative unitaries introduced in  @xcite and further studied in  @xcite .",
    "[ pro : compare_absorbers ] let @xmath155 and @xmath156 be two natural right absorbers for  @xmath3 .",
    "let @xmath157 , @xmath158 , @xmath159 , @xmath160 be the corresponding multiplicative unitaries .",
    "the unitaries @xmath161 satisfy the following pentagon - like equations : @xmath162 if the multiplicative unitaries @xmath163 and  @xmath164 are manageable , then @xmath165 and  @xmath166 give morphisms between the corresponding @xmath0-quantum groups that are inverse to each other in the category of @xmath0-quantum groups defined in  .",
    "our assumptions are symmetric in @xmath167 and @xmath168 .",
    "when we exchange them , the equations in the first column become the corresponding ones in the second column .",
    "so it suffices to prove those in the first column .",
    "we already know that @xmath169 is a right representation of  @xmath163 , which gives the first equation .",
    "the other equations are proved similarly . for the second equation",
    ", we use the naturality of  @xmath163 for the intertwiner @xmath170 and rewrite @xmath171 and @xmath172 . for the third equation , we use the naturality of  @xmath163 for the intertwiner @xmath173 and rewrite @xmath174 and @xmath172 .",
    "morphisms of quantum groups are described in @xcite*lemma 3.2 .",
    "the equations @xmath175 and @xmath176 say that  @xmath165 is a morphism from  @xmath164 to  @xmath163 .",
    "the equations @xmath177 and @xmath178 say that  @xmath166 is a morphism from  @xmath163 to  @xmath164 .",
    "the product of two morphisms is defined in  @xcite*definition 3.5 as the solution of a certain operator equation .",
    "the equation @xmath179 says that the product of @xmath165 and  @xmath166 is  @xmath163 .",
    "the equation @xmath180 says that the product of @xmath166 and  @xmath165 is  @xmath164 .",
    "manageability is needed in  @xcite to ensure that the equation in  @xcite*definition 3.5 always has a solution .",
    "so manageability is needed to talk about a _ category _ of morphisms between multiplicative unitaries .",
    "let @xmath167 be a natural right absorber for  @xmath3 and let @xmath181 .",
    "then @xmath182 with @xmath183 for all @xmath27 is a natural right absorber as well .",
    "the corresponding multiplicative unitary is @xmath184 proposition  [ pro : compare_absorbers ] shows that both natural right absorbers give isomorphic multiplicative unitaries , provided both multiplicative unitaries involved are manageable , compare @xcite*theorem 3.7 .",
    "we now extend the analysis above to describe functors between representation categories .",
    "let @xmath185 and  @xmath186 be hilbert space tensor categories with natural right absorbers @xmath187 and @xmath188 , respectively .",
    "let @xmath189 be a strict tensor functor with @xmath190 .",
    "if @xmath185 and  @xmath186 are representation categories , then this means that  @xmath191 turns a representation of one sort into one of the other _ on the same hilbert space _ in a natural way and preserving tensor products .",
    "such a functor also satisfies @xmath192 by the argument in remark  [ rem : trivial_unique ] .",
    "[ pro : functor_corep_morphism ] let @xmath189 be a strict tensor functor with @xmath190 .",
    "the unitary @xmath193 satisfies @xmath194 that is , @xmath195 is a bicharacter from  @xmath196 to  @xmath197 . moreover , for any @xmath198 , @xmath199 if the multiplicative unitary  @xmath196 is manageable and @xmath200 , then the map from functors @xmath201 as above to unitary bicharacters @xmath202 from  @xmath196 to  @xmath197 is bijective .",
    "if the multiplicative unitaries @xmath196 and  @xmath197 are both manageable , then @xmath195 is a morphism between the corresponding @xmath0-quantum groups in the category defined in  .",
    "the first two equations in the proposition say that  @xmath195 is a morphism of @xmath0-quantum groups as in @xcite*lemma 3.2 provided the multiplicative unitaries @xmath196 and  @xmath197 are manageable , so that they generate @xmath0-quantum groups .",
    "we already know that  @xmath195 is a right representation of  @xmath197 , which is the first equation .",
    "the second equation is the special case @xmath203 of the third one .",
    "the third equation says that the functor on representation categories induced by  @xmath195 is  @xmath191 , as expected .",
    "we prove this third equation by identifying @xmath204 and using the naturality of  @xmath205 for the intertwiner @xmath206 .",
    "this gives @xmath207 .",
    "the object  @xmath208 of  @xmath186 is determined uniquely by the corresponding representation @xmath209 of  @xmath197 by proposition  [ pro : absorber ] .",
    "this is given by @xmath210 .",
    "the action of  @xmath191 on arrows is determined by the faithful forgetful functor to hilbert spaces .",
    "so the unitary  @xmath195 determines the functor  @xmath191 .",
    "now assume that  @xmath196 is manageable .",
    "let @xmath202 be a bicharacter .",
    "we lift it to a functor  @xmath211 . given @xmath198 ,",
    "the operator  @xmath212 must be such that @xmath213 we may argue as in the proof of @xcite*lemma 3.6 to see that the operator on the right hand side of this equation is of the form @xmath209 for some unitary  @xmath212 and that the latter unitary is a representation of  @xmath197 .",
    "there is a unique functor @xmath214 with @xmath215 that sends @xmath27 to this representation and acts identically on arrows , viewed as hilbert space operators .",
    "this functor is a strict tensor functor as well .",
    "any functor  @xmath191 is of this form for the corresponding bicharacter  @xmath195 .",
    "this gives the desired bijection .",
    "proposition  [ pro : functor_corep_morphism ] gives yet another equivalent characterisation of the quantum group morphisms of  @xcite : they are equivalent to strict tensor functors between the representation categories with @xmath216 .",
    "this result is similar in spirit to @xcite*theorem 6.1 , which uses coactions on @xmath0-algebras instead of representations .",
    "a natural left absorber in  @xmath3 is defined like a natural right absorber , but on the other side :    [ def : natural_left_absorber ] a _ natural left absorber _ in  @xmath3 is an object @xmath217 together with unitaries @xmath218 with the following properties :    1 .",
    "the unitaries  @xmath219 are natural in the sense that the following diagram commutes for any arrow @xmath220 : @xmath107 {          \\lambda \\otimes x_1 &          \\lambda \\otimes { \\tau}(x_1)\\\\          \\lambda \\otimes x_2 &          \\lambda \\otimes { \\tau}(x_2)\\\\        } ;        { \\draw[cdar ] ( m-1 - 1 ) --    node[inner sep=1pt ] { \\(\\scriptstyle u_\\lambda^{x_1}\\ ) }    node[inner sep=1pt , swap ] { \\(\\scriptstyle \\cong\\ ) } ( m-1 - 2 ) ; } ;        { \\draw[cdar ] ( m-2 - 1 ) --    node[inner sep=1pt ] { \\(\\scriptstyle u_\\lambda^{x_2}\\ ) }    node[inner sep=1pt , swap ] { \\(\\scriptstyle \\cong\\ ) } ( m-2 - 2 ) ; } ;        { \\draw[cdar ] ( m-1 - 1 ) --    node[inner sep=1pt ] { \\(\\scriptstyle \\ ) }    node[inner sep=1pt , swap ] { \\(\\scriptstyle { \\textup{id}}_\\lambda \\otimes a\\ ) } ( m-2 - 1 ) ; } ;        { \\draw[cdar ] ( m-1 - 2 ) --    node[inner sep=1pt ] { \\(\\scriptstyle { \\textup{id}}_\\lambda \\otimes a\\ ) }    node[inner sep=1pt , swap ] { \\(\\scriptstyle \\ ) } ( m-2 - 2 ) ; } ;      \\end{tikzpicture}\\ ] ] 2 .   for @xmath13 the unitaries @xmath221 , @xmath222 and  @xmath223 are related by the following commuting diagram : @xmath111 {          \\lambda \\otimes x_1\\otimes x_2 &          \\lambda \\otimes { \\tau}(x_1\\otimes x_2)\\\\          \\lambda \\otimes { \\tau}(x_1)\\otimes x_2 &          \\lambda \\otimes { \\tau}(x_1)\\otimes { \\tau}(x_2)\\\\        } ;        { \\draw[cdar ] ( m-1 - 1 ) --    node[inner sep=1pt ] { \\(\\scriptstyle u_\\lambda^{x_1\\otimes x_2}\\ ) }    node[inner sep=1pt , swap ] { \\(\\scriptstyle \\ ) } ( m-1 - 2 ) ; } ;        { \\draw[cdar ] ( m-1 - 1 ) --    node[inner sep=1pt ] { \\(\\scriptstyle \\ ) }    node[inner sep=1pt , swap ] { \\(\\scriptstyle ( u_\\lambda^{x_1})_{12}\\ ) } ( m-2 - 1 ) ; } ;        { \\draw[cdar ] ( m-2 - 1 ) --    node[inner sep=1pt ] { \\(\\scriptstyle ( u_\\lambda^{x_2})_{13}\\ ) }    node[inner sep=1pt , swap ] { \\(\\scriptstyle \\ ) } ( m-2 - 2 ) ; } ;        \\draw[double , double equal sign distance ] ( m-1 - 2 ) -- ( m-2 - 2 ) ;      \\end{tikzpicture}\\ ] ]    the analogue of lemma  [ lem : natural_absorber_trivial ] holds for natural left absorbers as well , that is , @xmath224 for any hilbert space  @xmath28 .",
    "let  @xmath4 be a multiplicative unitary .",
    "then the categories of left and of right representations of  @xmath4 have a canonical natural _",
    "right _ absorber by examples [ exa : multunit_absorber ] and  [ exa : left_corep ] .",
    "it is unclear , in general , whether they have a natural left absorber as well . the only construction of left absorbers that we know uses the contragradient operation to turn a right into a left absorber . for contragradients to exist , we assume  @xmath4 to be manageable .",
    "we work with right representations of  @xmath4 to be definite .",
    "the contragradient of a representation  @xmath126 on a hilbert space  @xmath28 is a representation  @xmath225 on the complex - conjugate hilbert space  @xmath226 .",
    "the contragradient construction becomes a covariant functor @xmath227 when we map an intertwiner @xmath228 to @xmath229 .",
    "this is not quite a @xmath6-functor because it is conjugate - linear , not linear .",
    "the contragradient of a trivial representation remains trivial .",
    "the contragradient operation is involutive , that is , @xmath230 for representations and @xmath231 for intertwiners .",
    "it reverses the order of tensor factors : the flip operator @xmath232 intertwines @xmath233 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}\\widetilde{{\\mathbb{u}}_2}$ ] with the contragradient of @xmath234 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb{u}}_2 $ ] , see @xcite*section  3 .",
    "let @xmath235 be a natural right absorber for  @xmath43 .",
    "for instance , we may take the canonical one described in example  [ exa : multunit_absorber ] .",
    "let @xmath236 be the contragradient of  @xmath112 , so @xmath237 .",
    "let @xmath238 for @xmath239 be the composite unitary intertwiner @xmath240 routine computations show that @xmath241 is a natural left absorber if @xmath242 is a natural right absorber .",
    "this proves the following :    [ pro : left_right_absorber ] let  @xmath4 be a multiplicative unitary . if  @xmath4 is manageable , then its tensor category of representations  @xmath43 contains both a natural right absorber and a natural left absorber .",
    "if  @xmath3 has both a right absorber  @xmath112 and a left absorber  @xmath243 , then @xmath244 that is , the direct sums of infinitely many copies of @xmath243 and  @xmath112 are isomorphic .",
    "this common direct sum is both a left and a right absorber , and its isomorphism class does not depend on the choice of @xmath243 or  @xmath112 .",
    "these observations go back already to  @xcite , and they need only absorption , without any naturality .",
    "we are going to use the uniqueness of two - sided absorbers to prove that any isomorphism between the representation categories of two @xmath0-quantum groups comes from an isomorphism of hopf @xmath1-algebras .",
    "first we need a preparatory result , which would really belong into  @xcite , but was not proved there .",
    "[ the : isomorphisms_quantum_groups ] the isomorphisms in the category of @xmath0-quantum groups defined in  @xcite are the same as the hopf @xmath1-isomorphisms of the underlying @xmath0-bialgebras .",
    "it is trivial that a hopf @xmath1-isomorphism induces an isomorphism in the category of  @xcite .",
    "conversely , an isomorphism between two @xmath0-quantum groups @xmath245 , @xmath56 , in the category of  @xcite only gives a hopf @xmath1-isomorphism between their universal dual quantum groups @xmath246 ( or @xmath247 , but we shall use the dual isomorphism below ) .",
    "the hopf @xmath1-isomorphism @xmath248 induces an isomorphism between the representation categories of @xmath249 and @xmath250 .",
    "let @xmath251 , @xmath56 , be manageable multiplicative unitaries that generate @xmath245 .",
    "we view  @xmath252 as a right representation of @xmath245 on  @xmath253 .",
    "the representation of  @xmath254 associated to  @xmath252 descends to a faithful representation of  @xmath255 : this is the standard construction of @xmath256 from a multiplicative unitary in  @xcite .",
    "thus we have to prove that the representations of @xmath246 associated to @xmath257 and  @xmath258 have the same kernel . since our multiplicative unitaries are manageable , the representation category @xmath259 contains both a natural left and a natural right absorber by proposition  [ pro : left_right_absorber ] .",
    "both @xmath257 and  @xmath258 are natural right absorbers . by the remarks above , the direct sums @xmath260 and  @xmath261 of infinitely many copies of @xmath257 and  @xmath258 are isomorphic objects of  @xmath3 because they are both isomorphic to the direct sum of infinitely many copies of a natural left absorber .",
    "therefore , the representations of  @xmath262 associated to @xmath260 and  @xmath261 have the same kernel .",
    "then the representations of  @xmath262 associated to @xmath257 and  @xmath258 also have the same kernel .",
    "thus our hopf @xmath1-isomorphism @xmath246 descends to a hopf @xmath1-isomorphism @xmath263 .",
    "this implies a hopf @xmath1-isomorphism @xmath264 .",
    "[ cor : tannaka - krein ] a @xmath0-quantum group @xmath265 is determined uniquely by its tensor category @xmath266 of representations with the forgetful functor to  @xmath5 .",
    "let  @xmath4 be a manageable multiplicative unitary that generates the @xmath0-quantum group @xmath265 .",
    "then a representation of @xmath265 is equivalent to one of  @xmath4 on the same hilbert space , so that we may identify @xmath267 .",
    "now let @xmath249 and @xmath250 be two @xmath0-quantum groups .",
    "let @xmath257 and  @xmath258 be manageable multiplicative unitaries that generate them .",
    "these are natural right absorbers by example  [ exa : multunit_absorber ] .",
    "if @xmath268 , then proposition  [ pro : compare_absorbers ] shows that @xmath257 and  @xmath258 are isomorphic in the category of  @xcite .",
    "theorem  [ the : isomorphisms_quantum_groups ] shows that this isomorphism is a hopf @xmath1-isomorphism .",
    "proposition  [ pro : absorber ] has a variant for natural left absorbers .",
    "let @xmath243 and  @xmath113 be a natural left absorber for  @xmath3 . for @xmath27 , let @xmath128 , and write  @xmath105 for @xmath269 .",

    "namely , the unitaries @xmath281 satisfy the following pentagon - like equations : @xmath282 it is also interesting to apply the same technique to a tensor category with a natural right absorber @xmath155 and a natural left absorber @xmath283 .",

    "in addition , let  @xmath90 be any object of  @xmath3 .",
    "naturality of  @xmath164 with respect to the intertwiner @xmath289 gives @xmath290 naturality of  @xmath163 with respect to the intertwiner @xmath291 gives @xmath292 here @xmath105 and  @xmath293 are the representations of @xmath163 and  @xmath164 associated to  @xmath90 , respectively .",
    "so these determine each other .",
    "if @xmath294 for a manageable multiplicative unitary  @xmath163 and  @xmath164 comes from its contragradient as above , then also @xmath295 .",
    "so for a given representation  @xmath105 of  @xmath163 , there is a unique representation  @xmath293 of  @xmath164 satisfying  . and",
    "for a given representation  @xmath293 of  @xmath164 , there is a unique representation  @xmath105 of  @xmath163 satisfying  .",
    "multiplicative and antimultiplicative unitaries are closely related to the heisenberg and anti - heisenberg pairs studied in  @xcite . by definition , a heisenberg pair for a @xmath0-quantum group @xmath265",
    "is a pair of representations @xmath296 of @xmath297 such that @xmath298 for the reduced bicharacter @xmath299 is a multiplicative unitary .",
    "and an anti - heisenberg pair is a pair of representations @xmath300 of @xmath297 such that @xmath301 is an antimultiplicative unitary .",
    "let @xmath28 and  @xmath302 be hilbert spaces and let @xmath303 be a multiplicative unitary .",
    "let @xmath304 be a braided multiplicative unitary over  @xmath4 ( see  @xcite ) .",
    "we are first going to define a tensor category @xmath305 of right representations .",

    "this turns the representations of  @xmath306 into a @xmath6-category @xmath305 . forgetting both representations @xmath320 and  @xmath321 gives the forgetful functor to hilbert spaces .",
    "the functor @xmath23 maps @xmath322 . if the identity map on  @xmath45 is an intertwiner @xmath323 , then @xmath324 and @xmath325 .",

    "first , we ought to check that the tensor product above is well - defined , that is , gives representations again .",
    "we check associativity of the tensor product first because we want to use it to prove that the tensor product is again a representation .",
    "let @xmath331 and @xmath332 for @xmath333 be corepresentations of @xmath334 .",

    "therefore , @xmath349",
    "\\draw[- ] ( 0,0 ) -- ( 1.4ex,1.4ex ) node[right , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{k}}^1\\otimes{\\mathcal{k}}^2 $ } ;      \\draw[-,draw = white , line width=2.4pt ] ( 0,1.4ex ) -- ( 1.4ex,0 ) ;      \\draw[- ] ( 1.4ex,0 ) -- ( 0,1.4ex ) node[left , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{l}}$ } ;    \\end{tikzpicture } }    = z^{12}{\\sigma}_{23}{\\sigma}_{12 }    = z^2_{23}z^1_{13}{\\sigma}_{23}{\\sigma}_{12 }    = z^2_{23}{\\sigma}_{23}z^1_{12}{\\sigma}_{12 }    = { \\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline ]      \\draw[- ] ( 0,0 ) -- ( 1.4ex,1.4ex ) node[right , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{k}}^2 $ } ;      \\draw[-,draw = white , line width=2.4pt ] ( 0,1.4ex ) -- ( 1.4ex,0 ) ;      \\draw[- ] ( 1.4ex,0 ) -- ( 0,1.4ex ) node[left , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{l}}$ } ;    \\end{tikzpicture}}_{23}{\\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline ]      \\draw[- ] ( 0,0 ) -- ( 1.4ex,1.4ex ) node[right , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{k}}^1 $ } ;      \\draw[-,draw = white , line width=2.4pt ] ( 0,1.4ex ) -- ( 1.4ex,0 ) ;      \\draw[- ] ( 1.4ex,0 ) -- ( 0,1.4ex ) node[left , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{l}}$ } ;    \\end{tikzpicture}}_{12}.\\ ] ] similarly , @xmath328",

    "the proof will also help to construct a natural right absorber later .",
    "we claim that an operator @xmath310 together with @xmath350 gives a representation if and only if  @xmath321 is an intertwiner @xmath351 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ;     "assume we know this for @xmath353 and @xmath354 .",
    "since  @xmath355 is equivariant , when we conjugate it with the braiding operator @xmath356      \\draw[- ] ( 0,0 ) -- ( 1.4ex,1.4ex ) node[right , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{k}}^2 \\otimes { \\mathcal{l}}$ } ;      \\draw[-,draw = white , line width=2.4pt ] ( 0,1.4ex ) -- ( 1.4ex,0 ) ;      \\draw[- ] ( 1.4ex,0 ) -- ( 0,1.4ex ) node[left , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{l}}$ } ;    \\end{tikzpicture}})_{234}$ ] on @xmath357 , then we merely transfer it to  @xmath358 , which commutes with  @xmath359 .",

\\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb{t}}^2 $ ] has the expected intertwining property to be a representation .",
    "now we check assumption  [ assum : arrow_cancellative ] .",
    "let @xmath364 be such that @xmath365 is an intertwiner for the tensor product representation .",
    "since  @xmath40 commutes with  @xmath366 , the equivariance with respect to @xmath367 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb{s}}^2 $ ] gives that  @xmath40 is @xmath347-equivariant .",
    "since  @xmath368 commutes with @xmath338 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb{t}}^2 $ ] , @xmath356      \\draw[- ] ( 0,0 ) -- ( 1.4ex,1.4ex ) node[right , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{k}}^2 \\otimes { \\mathcal{k}}^3 $ } ;      \\draw[-,draw = white , line width=2.4pt ] ( 0,1.4ex ) -- ( 1.4ex,0 ) ;      \\draw[- ] ( 1.4ex,0 ) -- ( 0,1.4ex ) node[left , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{l}}$ } ;    \\end{tikzpicture}})_{234}$ ] , and @xmath355 , it follows that  @xmath40 is an intertwiner for  @xmath359 as well .",
    "[ pro : braided_absorber ] the representation @xmath369 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb{u } } ,    1{\\mathbin{\\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline , x=.75ex , y=.75ex ] \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb f})\\ ] ] is a natural right absorber for the tensor category @xmath305 .",
    "we must construct an intertwiner @xmath370 for any representation @xmath371 of @xmath306 .",
    "we claim that the composite operator @xmath372 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb w^{}}{\\mathbin{\\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline , x=.75ex , y=.75ex ] \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}1_{{\\mathcal{h } } } { \\mathbin{\\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline , x=.75ex , y=.75ex ] \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb f } )    \\end{gathered}\\ ] ] has the properties required in definition  [ def : natural_absorber ] .",
    "the triple @xmath373 is a representation of @xmath306 for any right representation  @xmath320 of  @xmath4 , and a map between representations of this form is an intertwiner if and only if it is an intertwiner for the representations of  @xmath4 . in particular , the second map  @xmath374 above is an intertwiner , see example  [ exa : multunit_absorber ] .",
    "moreover , since there are representations @xmath375 and @xmath376 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb w^ { } } ,    { \\mathbb f}{\\mathbin{\\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline , x=.75ex , y=.75ex ] \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}1)$ ] , the map @xmath335 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}1_{{\\mathcal{h}}}$ ] above is an intertwiner as well , see the proof of lemma  [ lem : corep_braided ] .",
    "thus the composite map is an intertwiner @xmath377 as needed .",
    "these two operators and their composite are natural by construction , that is , [ en : natural_absorber1 ] holds .",
    "we check condition [ en : natural_absorber2 ] .",
    "let @xmath378 be representations of @xmath306 .",
    "we shall use the diagram in figure  [ fig : braided_corep_absorber ] .",

    "they are intertwiners of braided representations , compare  .",
    "the remaining arrows are also intertwiners of braided representations by the proof of lemma  [ lem : corep_braided ] . before we show that the diagram in figure  [ fig : braided_corep_absorber ] commutes , we deduce the condition [ en : natural_absorber2 ] from it .",

\\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}f ) ,    \\end{gathered}\\ ] ] compare the proof in lemma  [ lem : corep_braided ] that the tensor product is associative . and the arrow going downward from there is @xmath394 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb{s}}^2)_{123}$ ] .",
    "so the composite arrow is the absorbing intertwiner for the tensor product @xmath395 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb{s}}^2 ,    { \\mathbb{t}}^1{\\mathbin{\\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline , x=.75ex , y=.75ex ] \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb{t}}^2)$ ]",
    ". similarly , the arrows labeled @xmath396 and  @xmath397 are the absorbing intertwiners for @xmath398 and @xmath399 , respectively .",
    "hence the commutativity of the boundary of the diagram in figure  [ fig : braided_corep_absorber ] is exactly [ en : natural_absorber2 ] .",
    "now we check that the diagram in figure  [ fig : braided_corep_absorber ] commutes .",
    "the four triangles of braiding operators commute because the braiding operators have enough of the properties of a braided monoidal category , compare the proof in lemma  [ lem : corep_braided ] .",
    "the two pentagons with @xmath397 and  @xmath396 as one of the faces commute by definition of our absorbing intertwiners .",
    "the two parallelograms with  @xmath348 and braiding operators commute because the braiding operators are natural with respect to intertwiners of @xmath4-representations .",
    "the square with @xmath359 and  @xmath400 commutes because we operate on different legs .",
    "finally , we consider the square involving  @xmath401 and the braiding operator @xmath328      \\draw[- ] ( 1.4ex,0 ) -- ( 0,1.4ex ) node[left , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{k}}^2 $ } ;      \\draw[-,draw = white , line width=2.4pt ] ( 0,0 ) -- ( 1.4ex,1.4ex ) ;      \\draw[- ] ( 0,0 ) -- ( 1.4ex,1.4ex ) node[right , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{l}}$ } ;    \\end{tikzpicture}}$ ] . here",
    "@xmath329 carries the trivial representation of  @xmath4 , so that the braiding is just the tensor flip  @xmath402 .",
    "thus the square commutes , and now we have seen that the entire diagram commutes .    [ the : braided_to_multunit ]",
    "the operator @xmath403 is a multiplicative unitary such that there is a fully faithful , strict tensor functor @xmath404 with @xmath216 .",
    "the functor  @xmath191 maps a representation @xmath307 of @xmath306 to the following representation of  @xmath405 : @xmath406 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}1_{{\\mathcal{h } } } )    = { \\mathbb{s}}_{12 } { \\hat{{\\mathbb{v}}}}_{23}^ * { \\mathbb{t}}_{13 } { \\hat{{\\mathbb{v}}}}_{23 }    \\in { \\mathcal u}({\\mathcal{k}}\\otimes{\\mathcal{h}}\\otimes{\\mathcal{l}}).\\ ] ] the functor  @xmath191 is an isomorphism of categories if @xmath405 and  @xmath4 are manageable .",
    "we have found a natural right absorber @xmath407 in proposition  [ pro : braided_absorber ] .",
    "proposition  [ pro : absorber ] shows that  @xmath408 is a multiplicative unitary and that @xmath409 is a fully faithful , strict tensor functor @xmath410 . by definition , @xmath411 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ;      \\draw[-,draw = white , line width=2.4pt ] ( 0,0 ) -- ( 1.4ex,1.4ex ) ;      \\draw[- ] ( 0,0 ) -- ( 1.4ex,1.4ex ) node[right , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{l}}$ } ;    \\end{tikzpicture}})^{\\phantom1}_{23}$ ] and , in particular , @xmath412 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ;      \\draw[-,draw = white , line width=2.4pt ] ( 0,1.4ex ) -- ( 1.4ex,0 ) ;      \\draw[- ] ( 1.4ex,0 ) -- ( 0,1.4ex ) node[left , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{l}}$ } ;    \\end{tikzpicture}})_{34 }    { \\mathbb f}_{23 }    ( { \\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline ]      \\draw[- ] ( 1.4ex,0 ) -- ( 0,1.4ex ) node[left , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{h}}$ } ;      \\draw[-,draw = white , line width=2.4pt ] ( 0,0 ) -- ( 1.4ex,1.4ex ) ;      \\draw[- ] ( 0,0 ) -- ( 1.4ex,1.4ex ) node[right , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{l}}$ } ;    \\end{tikzpicture}})^{\\phantom1}_{34}.\\ ] ] the definition and   give the braiding unitary @xmath328      \\draw[- ] ( 0,0 ) -- ( 1.4ex,1.4ex ) node[right , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{h}}$ } ;      \\draw[-,draw = white , line width=2.4pt ] ( 0,1.4ex ) -- ( 1.4ex,0 ) ;      \\draw[- ] ( 1.4ex,0 ) -- ( 0,1.4ex ) node[left , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{l}}$ } ;    \\end{tikzpicture } } \\in { \\mathcal u}({\\mathcal{l}}\\otimes    { \\mathcal{h}},{\\mathcal{h}}\\otimes { \\mathcal{l}})$ ] is equal to  @xmath413 for the unique unitary @xmath414 that verifies the following equation : @xmath415 compare @xcite*(6.10 ) . as a left representation of  @xmath4",
    ", @xmath330 satisfies @xmath416 .",
    "hence @xmath417 .",
    "since @xmath418 , we get the asserted formulas for @xmath419 and  @xmath408 . we still have to prove that every representation of  @xmath405 comes from one of @xmath306 .",
    "this will take a while and require some further results .",
    "this proof will be completed at the end of this article .",
    "[ pro : projection_on_c ] the operators @xmath420 and @xmath421 are bicharacters from the multiplicative unitary  @xmath405 to @xmath42 and back , whose composite from  @xmath405 to itself is equal to @xmath422 .",
    "equivalently , the following pentagon - like equations hold : @xmath423    there are two obvious strict tensor functors between the hilbert space tensor categories @xmath305 and @xmath43 , namely , the forgetful functor @xmath424 and the functor @xmath425 the definitions imply immediately that these are strict tensor functors that are compatible with the forgetful functors to  @xmath5 .",
    "both tensor categories involved have natural right absorbers , and the associated multiplicative unitaries are @xmath405 and  @xmath4 , respectively .",
    "proposition  [ pro : functor_corep_morphism ] produces bicharacters from strict tensor functors like the ones above .",
    "furthermore , the composite functor on  @xmath43 is the identity .",
    "correspondingly , the composite bicharacter from  @xmath4 to itself is the bicharacter that describes the identity functor , which is  @xmath4 itself . and the composite bicharacter from  @xmath405 to itself is idempotent , which means that it satisfies the pentagon equation itself .",
    "it remains to make explicit which bicharacters we get from the formulas in proposition  [ pro : functor_corep_morphism ] .",
    "the bicharacter describing the functor @xmath426 is the canonical unitary intertwiner @xmath427 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb{u } } = { \\mathbb w^{}}_{13}{\\mathbb{u}}_{23}\\colon    ( { \\mathcal{h}}\\otimes{\\mathcal{l } } , { \\mathbb w^{}}{\\mathbin{\\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline , x=.75ex , y=.75ex ] \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb{u } } ) \\otimes    ( { \\mathcal{h}},{\\mathbb w^ { } } ) \\to    ( { \\mathcal{h}}\\otimes{\\mathcal{l } } , 1 ) \\otimes    ( { \\mathcal{h}},{\\mathbb w^{}}),\\ ] ]",
    "that is , we get @xmath428 .",
    "the bicharacter describing the functor @xmath429 is the natural isomorphism @xmath430 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb f } )    \\to    ( { \\mathcal{h}},1,1 ) \\otimes    ( { \\mathcal{h}}\\otimes{\\mathcal{l } } ,    { \\mathbb w^{}}\\otimes{\\mathbb{u } } ,    1{\\mathbin{\\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline , x=.75ex , y=.75ex ] \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb f})\\ ] ] described during the proof of proposition  [ pro : braided_absorber ] . since the representation of  @xmath314 is  @xmath431 here , this simplifies to the unitary @xmath432 .    by the definition of the composition of bicharacters in @xcite*definition 3.5 , the composite bicharacter from  @xmath405 to itself",
    "is  @xmath433 if and only if the following equation holds : @xmath434 indeed , the representation property of  @xmath126 and the pentagon equation for  @xmath4 give @xmath435 as desired .",
    "the general theory says that all these unitaries are bicharacters and that the bicharacter  @xmath436 is idempotent , that is , satisfies the pentagon equation .",
    "it remains to prove that every representation of  @xmath405 comes from a representation of the braided multiplicative unitary if  @xmath405 is manageable .",
    "that is , we want it to be of the form @xmath437 for some representation @xmath307 of @xmath306 .",
    "so we start with a representation @xmath438 of  @xmath405 .",
    "the hilbert space must remain  @xmath45 .",
    "we have described the functor @xmath439 through the bicharacter @xmath440 from  @xmath405 to  @xmath4 in proposition  [ pro : projection_on_c ] .",
    "proposition  [ pro : functor_corep_morphism ] shows that @xmath441 satisfies @xmath442 this equation determines  @xmath320 uniquely , and it exists because the multiplicative unitary  @xmath4 is manageable . now  @xmath321 should satisfy @xmath443 , that is , @xmath444 it remains to prove , first , that the right hand side has trivial second leg , so that it comes from a unitary @xmath310 ; and , secondly , that @xmath307 is a representation of @xmath306 .",
    "since these computations are quite unpleasant , we proceed indirectly . for the purpose of this proof",
    ", we say that a representation of  @xmath405 _ comes from a braided representation _ if it belongs to the image of the functor @xmath445 .",
    "[ lem : lift_cancel ] let @xmath446 and @xmath447 be representations of  @xmath405 . if @xmath446 and @xmath448 \\draw[line width=.2pt ]",
    "( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb{a}}^2)$ ] come from braided representations , then so does @xmath447 .",
    "we define  @xmath449 and  @xmath450 for @xmath56 as above . we know that @xmath399 is a braided representation .",
    "but at first , we only know @xmath451 .",
    "we may , nevertheless , recycle the diagram in figure  [ fig : braided_corep_absorber ] , treating it as a diagram in @xmath43 only , and replacing the top left arrow @xmath355 by @xmath452 .",
    "the two pentagons still commute by definition of @xmath453 .",
    "the four triangles of braiding operators in figure  [ fig : braided_corep_absorber ] commute as before .",
    "so do the parallelograms containing @xmath366 and braiding operators , and the two squares in the middle : this only needs @xmath454 to be a braided representation , which we have assumed .",
    "hence the entire diagram commutes . the composite arrow from the @xmath391-entry to the @xmath455-entry",
    "is the tensor product representation @xmath456 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb{a}}^2 $ ] .",
    "we have assumed that this comes from a braided representation .",
    "this must be of the form @xmath457 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb{s}}^2,{\\mathbb{t}})$ ] for some @xmath458 . hence",
    "@xmath459      \\draw[- ] ( 1.4ex,0 ) -- ( 0,1.4ex ) node[left , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{k}}^2 $ } ;      \\draw[-,draw = white , line width=2.4pt ] ( 0,0 ) -- ( 1.4ex,1.4ex ) ;      \\draw[- ] ( 0,0 ) -- ( 1.4ex,1.4ex ) node[right , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{l}}$ } ;    \\end{tikzpicture}})_{23 }    { \\mathbb{t}}^1_{12 }    ( { \\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline ]      \\draw[- ] ( 0,0 ) -- ( 1.4ex,1.4ex ) node[right , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{k}}^2 $ } ;      \\draw[-,draw = white , line width=2.4pt ] ( 0,1.4ex ) -- ( 1.4ex,0 ) ;      \\draw[- ] ( 1.4ex,0 ) -- ( 0,1.4ex ) node[left , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{l}}$ } ;    \\end{tikzpicture}})_{23 }    { \\mathbb{t}}^2_{234 }    = { \\mathbb{t}}_{123}.\\ ] ] therefore , @xmath452 acts trivially on the fourth leg .",
    "so @xmath460 for some @xmath354 . in the proof of lemma  [",
    "lem : corep_braided ] , we have shown that a unitary  @xmath321 in @xmath461 together with a representation  @xmath462 of  @xmath4 is a braided representation if and only if @xmath321 is an intertwiner from @xmath335 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb f}$ ] to @xmath335 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}1_{{\\mathcal{l}}}$ ] .",
    "therefore , @xmath338 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb{t}}^2=    ( { \\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline ]      \\draw[- ] ( 0,0 ) -- ( 1.4ex,1.4ex ) node[right , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{k}}^2 $ } ;      \\draw[-,draw = white , line width=2.4pt ] ( 0,1.4ex ) -- ( 1.4ex,0 ) ;      \\draw[- ] ( 1.4ex,0 ) -- ( 0,1.4ex ) node[left , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{l}}$ } ;    \\end{tikzpicture}})^{\\phantom1}_{23 } { \\mathbb{t}}^1_{12 }    ( { \\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline ]      \\draw[- ] ( 1.4ex,0 ) -- ( 0,1.4ex ) node[left , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{k}}^2 $ } ;      \\draw[-,draw = white , line width=2.4pt ] ( 0,0 ) -- ( 1.4ex,1.4ex ) ;      \\draw[- ] ( 0,0 ) -- ( 1.4ex,1.4ex ) node[right , inner sep=0pt ] { $ \\scriptstyle { \\mathcal{l}}$ } ;    \\end{tikzpicture}})^{\\phantom1}_{23 }    { \\mathbb{t}}^2_{23}$ ] and @xmath401 are intertwiners of braided representations .",
    "so are the braiding operators , compare  .",
    "hence @xmath463 is an intertwiner of braided representations .",
    "then so is  @xmath464 itself .",
    "this means that  @xmath465 is a braided representation .",
    "since  @xmath405 is manageable , proposition  [ pro : left_right_absorber ] shows that  @xmath43 contains a ( natural ) left absorber  @xmath466 .",
    "even more , the proof shows that we may choose  @xmath466 to be isomorphic to a direct sum of copies of  @xmath405 . by definition",
    ", @xmath405 comes from the braided representation @xmath467 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb{u } } , 1_{{\\mathcal{h } } } { \\mathbin{\\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline , x=.75ex , y=.75ex ] \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb f})$ ] .",
    "hence the direct sum of countably many summands of  @xmath405 also comes from a braided representation . since @xmath468 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ;",
    "\\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb{a}}^2 \\cong { \\mathbb{a}}^1 { \\mathbin{\\begin{tikzpicture}[baseline , x=.75ex , y=.75ex ] \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}1_{{\\mathcal{k}}^2 } \\cong { \\mathbb{a}}^1 $ ] for any representation  @xmath447 , @xmath468 \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( -0.8,1.15)--(0.8,1.15);\\draw[line width=.2pt](0,-0.25)--(0,1.15 ) ; \\draw[line width=.2pt ] ( 0,0.75 ) circle [ radius = 1];\\end{tikzpicture}}}{\\mathbb{a}}^2 $ ] also comes from a braided representation .",
    "now lemma  [ lem : lift_cancel ] shows that any representation  @xmath447 of  @xmath405 comes from a braided representation .",
    "this finishes the proof of theorem  [ the : braided_to_multunit ] ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we use the theory of regular objects in tensor categories to clarify the passage between braided multiplicative unitaries and multiplicative unitaries with projection . </S>",
    "<S> the braided multiplicative unitary and its semidirect product multiplicative unitary have the same hilbert space representations . </S>",
    "<S> we also show that the multiplicative unitaries associated to two regular objects for the same tensor category are equivalent and hence generate isomorphic @xmath0-quantum groups . </S>",
    "<S> in particular , a @xmath0-quantum group is determined uniquely by its tensor category of representations on hilbert space , and any functor between representation categories that does not change the underlying hilbert spaces comes from a morphism of @xmath0-quantum groups . </S>"
  ]
}
